Legislature To Consider Bill
To Help Finance Student Aid
BY ROBERT INSOFT
In a continuing attempt to
reduce the burden of increasing
tuition costs, university officials
are lobbying for passage of a bill
in the present session of the
Maryland State Assembly that
would allow institutions such as
Johns Hopkins to float tax-free
bonds in order to finance more
student loans at lower rates.
Spearheaded by the Maryland Independent Colleges and
Universities Association, the
specific legislative bill will be
designed to create new authority
which would allow Hopkins, as
well as other Maryland colleges,
to borrow money tax free so
larger student loans at lower
interest rates would be possible.
Governor Harry Hughes has
already announced his support
of the bill, and Hopkins President Steven Muller hopes to play
an active role in lobbying for the
bill.
According
to
Ellery
Woodworth of the University's
Office of Governmental Affairs,
the bill still needs to be approved by MICUA's Executive
Director Elizabeth Garraway, as
well as members representing
other Maryland independent colleges. After the final approval
process, the bill will be introduced within the next few weeks
as an "administration bill" filed
on behalf of the Governor by

the Speaker of the House and
the President of the State
Senate.
The attractiveness of the
new proposal, as seen by Muller,
is that "it would not cost state
taxpayers a cent"; the state
legislature need only approve the
tax exempt status to permit the
floating of the tax free bonds.
The bonds would be backed
solely by the institutions that
issue them. "We would borrow
at a lower rate than if they were
taxable bonds and then lend to
students at the lower rate,"
Muller explained. Since the new
low interest rate requires capital,
the extra funds will in turn come
from the Student Aid Budget.
However, according to Director
of Financial Aid Susan Broadbent, a tremendous amount of
money would still have to be
invested by Hopkins to make the
bonds more attractive to prospective investors.
Woodworth also added that
passage of the bill is now necessary, because "Reaganomics has
driven colleges to look for other
sources of support for their
students." If the bill is passed
during this legislative session,
the law will be enacted June 1.
Woodworth hopes that if bond
sales proceed, the resulting student money should become
available at Hopkins as early as
January 1983.
The state of Illinois has

already passed legislation under
a similar plan. However, one
drawback of the Illinois program
is that only state residents can
receive the loans. The Hopkins
backers of the Maryland bill are
hoping to circumvent this obstacle since a large number of
Hopkins loan recipients are from
out of state.
Although plans to implement the loan program are still

program will be run similar to

Union Board To Send
Students To Bahamas
The Hopkins Student Union
Board is sponsoring a three-day
trip for two to the Bahamas over
the Washington's Birthday weekend.
The trip is the prize for
winners of a drawing, to be held
at the Union Board's Bahamas
Night Party on Thursday. Feb.
11, from 9 p.m. to 1 a.m.
Admission to the party is $10
per couple, and pays for tropical
drinks, eats, and dancing. The
party will be held in the Glass
Pavilion, and, according to
Associate Director of Student
Services Mary Ellen Porter,
"Hawaiian dress is encouraged."
"The Union Board wanted
to do something different than
the typical beer bash," said
Porter. "The idea has been
kicking around for a few years,
but it was only this year that a
charter flight offered by a travel
agency and the air fare cuts
made it possible."

Porter said that all Hopkins
students, Goucher and Peabody
students, and other JHU affiliates, can enter the drawing. She
stressed, however, that -all entrants must have proof of U.S.
citizenship in the form of either
a passport, a birth certificate or
a notarized copy of a birth
certificate, or a voter registration
card; without one of these, the
winners will not be able to enter
the Bahamas.
The winners will spend Feb.
12 through 15 in Freeport, with
all expenses paid except for
meals.
"No one will miss a Monday
class either, because it's Washington's Birthday," Porter said.
